articles.headline: Court Rejects Same-Sex Marriage Ban in California
articles.snippet: A federal judge struck down a voter-approved ban on gay marriage, handing a temporary victory to gay rights advocates in a legal battle likely to be settled by the Supreme Court.
articles.abstract: A federal judge struck down a voter-approved ban on gay marriage, handing a temporary victory to gay rights advocates in a legal battle likely to be settled by the Supreme Court.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Saying that it discriminates against gay men and women, a federal judge in San Francisco struck down California’s voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage on Wednesday, handing supporters of such unions at least a temporary victory in a legal battle that seems all but certain to be settled by the Supreme Court.
articles.byline: By Jesse McKinley and John Schwartz

articles.headline: Vice, a Media Company, Shows Big Brands How to Reach the Hip Crowd
articles.snippet: In 2009, companies spent more than $47 billion on custom marketing — from magazines to Web sites — to attract specific audiences.
articles.abstract: In 2009, companies spent more than $47 billion on custom marketing — from magazines to Web sites — to attract specific audiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vice is happy to be known as a hipster media company. From its headquarters in a former warehouse in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, the company oversees magazines covering youth culture in 23 editions distributed in 26 countries, an online television network and a record label.

articles.headline: For Fannie Stock, Even Betting Pennies Is a Risk
articles.snippet: Shares of the mortgage giant Fannie Mae are almost worthless, but they are trading hands at a furious pace.
articles.abstract: Shares of the mortgage giant Fannie Mae are almost worthless, but they are trading hands at a furious pace.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is flotsam of the housing wreck, a stock no longer worthy of the Big Board. But penny by penny, the mortgage giant Fannie Mae is being salvaged in the stock market.

articles.headline: Ex-Meredith Officer to Be Time’s Chief
articles.snippet: Another shake-up is taking place in the magazine industry as Jack Griffin, formerly of Meredith, is expected to replace Ann Moore, the head of Time Inc.
articles.abstract: Another shake-up is taking place in the magazine industry as Jack Griffin, formerly of Meredith, is expected to replace Ann Moore, the head of Time Inc.
articles.lead_paragraph: The shake-up of the magazine industry’s corner offices will continue next week as Time Warner is expected to announce that Jack Griffin, the former Meredith Corporation executive, will become chief executive at Time Inc., succeeding Ann S. Moore.

articles.headline: Google and Verizon Near Deal on Web Pay Tiers
articles.snippet: An agreement could lay the foundation for a system in which companies would pay to move their content faster.
articles.abstract: An agreement could lay the foundation for a system in which companies would pay to move their content faster.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Google and Verizon, two leading players in Internet service and content, are nearing an agreement that could allow Verizon to speed some online content to Internet users more quickly if the content’s creators are willing to pay for the privilege.

articles.headline: Outsourcing to India Draws Western Lawyers
articles.snippet: American and British lawyers — who might once have turned up their noses at the idea of moving to India — are re-evaluating.
articles.abstract: American and British lawyers — who might once have turned up their noses at the idea of moving to India — are re-evaluating.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOIDA, India — As an assistant attorney general for New York State, Christopher Wheeler used to spend most of his time arguing in courtrooms in New York City.

articles.headline: Oil Rig’s Owner Had Safety Issue at Three Other Wells
articles.snippet: Confidential reports by Transocean, the owner of the Deepwater Horizon rig, offer an unusually candid view of safety and maintenance concerns.
articles.abstract: Confidential reports by Transocean, the owner of the Deepwater Horizon rig, offer an unusually candid view of safety and maintenance concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: The company that owned the oil rig that exploded in the Gulf of Mexico in April had widespread safety concerns about several of its other rigs in the gulf, and a month before the disaster it commissioned a broad review of the safety culture of the company’s North American operations, according to confidential internal reports.

articles.headline: In Gulf, Good News Is Taken With Grain of Salt
articles.snippet: Reports that the oil has been rapidly breaking down have been met with skepticism.
articles.abstract: Reports that the oil has been rapidly breaking down have been met with skepticism.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  There is little celebration on the Gulf Coast.

articles.headline: Sales Were Sluggish in July for Retailers
articles.snippet: The weak spending raises worries about the health of the back-to-school season as Americans step up saving amid a stalling recovery.
articles.abstract: The weak spending raises worries about the health of the back-to-school season as Americans step up saving amid a stalling recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: The second half of the year is off to a slow start for retailers, who reported Thursday that sales at stores open at least a year were weaker than expected in July, increasing 2.9 percent from July of last year, according to a tally by Thomson Reuters.

articles.headline: Russia, Crippled by Drought, Bans Grain Exports
articles.snippet: The abrupt intervention, a response to Russia’s record heat, drove U.S. wheat prices to their highest levels in two years.
articles.abstract: The abrupt intervention, a response to Russia’s record heat, drove U.S. wheat prices to their highest levels in two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday banned all exports of grain after millions of acres of Russian wheat withered in a severe drought, driving up prices around the world and pushing them to their highest level in two years in the United States.
